nodeMetric.field_description:
Net Profit is the value that remains after all operating expenses are subtracted from a company’s revenue. Net Profit is one of the best ways to determine a business' profitability and is often referred to as the bottom line. 

For Net Income, expenses to be deducted include Cost of Goods Sold (COGS), all operating expenses, and tax and interest costs.
field_formula: (Revenue - COGS - Operating Expenses - Taxes - Interest Expenses)

body.summary: Net Profit is the value that remains after all operating expenses are subtracted from a company’s revenue.

field_related_metrics.field_metricname: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
field_related_metrics.field_description: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA) is one of a few profit metrics. At its simplest, EBITDA focuses only on operational profitability, ignoring non-cash expenses by adding them back to Net Income.

The Cost Of Goods Sold (COGS) is the measure of costs incurred by a company to manufacture or resell a product. Costs typically include raw material and direct labour, but this varies from business to business, depending on the products or services that are being sold. COGS is the building block to understanding Gross Margin and Gross Margin Percent.

Gross Profit is the amount left over from total revenues after Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) has been deducted. COGS will typically include the cost of making and selling the product or the cost of services provided by the company.
